awd_titl_txt: Learning physics by practicing it with physical apparatus or using interactive video: is there a difference?
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance understanding of how students develop scientific reasoning abilities when using an online resource. Education is shifting rapidly from traditional classrooms and laboratories to more flexible, online learning environments in which students do not always have access to physical equipment. Research has shown that students can learn scientific abilities through collaborative hands-on investigative experiences and subsequent analyses and discussions. This project will explore the extent to which those same scientific abilities can be developed using high-quality interactive videos of experiments.

This project will couple the flexibility of web-based video technology with the Investigative Science Learning Environment (ISLE), a pedagogical framework that leads students through processes of scientific reasoning used by practicing scientists. The ISLE framework, most often implemented in a traditional setting where lecture is separated from apparatus-based lab experimentation, has already been shown to improve students' scientific reasoning abilities. Today e-learning resources such as this project's video-based ISLE (vISLE) are blurring the lines between lecture and lab and opening up the possibilities for authentic scientific investigations in non-traditional settings. The goals of this project are: A) to gain a deeper and more nuanced understanding of how students engage in science practices using an e-learning resource such as vISLE. Do students learn fundamental physics principles using vISLE and what scientific reasoning abilities or habits of mind do they display and develop using vISLE? and B) to gain an understanding of how the advantages of videos can be exploited to extend authentic scientific investigations into non-traditional venues (such as in the classroom or in a homework assignment).

por.por_cntn:
Our project aimed to develop, implement and study new educational resources and methods that are well-adapted to the 21st century. Students need to learn more than scientific facts, students need to learn about the practices of science from their physics courses. These scientific practices are critical to the future success of students entering the 21st century workplace. Likewise, the evolution of learning in the internet-age implies that students will engage in learning scientific practices in non-traditional settings such as online learning environments as opposed to a physical brick-and-mortar classroom/lab. Understanding this process is critical to the development of 21st century learning which is increasingly becoming a blend of virtual and in-person learning. As researchers and educators we recognize that there is a new and difficult path to navigate: online and virtual learning is now a fact of life. The critical challenge is, how do we implement everything we know about what makes learning effective in terms of peer collaboration and hands-on activities, in virtual learning environments? Our project has contributed significantly to understanding this challenge in the following ways.

a. We developed and refined (through multiple iterations) a set of 5 learning cycles on 5 introductory physics topics, a total of 20 interactive video-based experimentation activities specifically designed to lead students through an investigative process that mirrors the practices of science. The framework of Pivot Interactives allows students to take measurements from a video of a physics experiment using embedded html 5 measurement tools. A matrix of videos allows students to alter experimental variables. These features allow them to make many of the same investigative decisions they would have to make in conducting a physics experiment using physical apparatus in a brick-and-mortar lab.

b. Through the iterative process of refining these activities we discovered that students need more guidance and support as well as ways to collaborate when working together in a virtual learning environment. These changes were incorporated into the activities we developed and into the Pivot Interactives platform.

c. We conducted an experimental study that showed that students develop scientific reasoning abilities and habits of mind when engaging in experimentation activities using videos in place of physical equipment. Their development of scientific reasoning abilities was comparable to students who performed the same experiments using physical apparatus. There were also some subtle differences in how students learn about data analysis and experimental uncertainties, that we attribute to the different affordances of video-based experimentation versus experimenting with the actual physical apparatus. In summary, our data show that students can conduct authentic scientific investigations using video-based experimentation activities.

d. Through an implementation study with multiple instructors at different institutions we discovered that students find experimentation activities using videos slightly more challenging than doing the same activities with physical apparatus in a brick-and-mortar classroom. We hypothesize that this could be either because of the reduced opportunity to collaborate with peers and/or the reduced set of representational tools available to students when conducting an experimentation activity without the physical apparatus. This connects to our final finding below.

e. Through qualitative analysis of videos of groups of students engaging in activities either with the physical apparatus or using video-based experiments, we have found that students use the physical apparatus as a representational tool when engaging in sense-making. This is not a novel discovery, but what is new is that students who engage in sense-making with video-based experiments tended to employ a rich repertoire of gestures and often appeared to be manipulating an imaginary piece of apparatus with their hands when they engage in similar episodes of sense-making. More research is needed, but it is possible that students need the physical apparatus as a representational resource and removing this representational channel, by having students use videos in place of physical apparatus, may make the sense-making process more challenging for students.
